name: North Stein River
description: Remote, multiday, hike in, hard core creeking.  Includes a pleasant paddle out on the main Stein.

name: Mamquam River
description: A fun and scenic class III+ stretch on the Upper Mamquam. The last two kilometres known as the Middle Mamquam is class IV, but please see the dam warning. The Mamquam gauge is newly online so we have yet to establish a solid correlation. 45-55cms translates to a nice low or medium-low level (though note that this still has a big volume feel for the last two kilometres). The gauge is quite far downstream (near town), so the correlation may not be consistent.

name: Big Creek
description: Scrappy, dangerous whitewater through a remote canyon In most years the thin alpine snowpack melts off early during May and June, possibly extending into July. While there are small glaciers in the alpine headwaters, they are not big enough to sustain runnable flows through the summer. In some years (e.g. 2019), major summer thunderstorms can hit the Chilcotin Plateau, and the large area of this plateau can lead to flooding, but in most years this run will be done by July. The information here is from a descent at 12cms in July 2020 ( BIG CREEK ABO

name: Williams Creek
description: The local home run, with high quality smooth granite boulders and bedrock.

name: Bridge River
description: Low Water Boulder garden run which occasionally has releases.

name: Soo River
description: A short, stout addition to the classic section of the Soo.  Easy access canyon with big holes.

name: Klastline
description: A northern BC adventure. Remote and with only a handful of descents the Klastline is a good option for anyone who plans to be in the area and wants to run something other than the Stikine. Some class 4 bedrock rapids, 2 big waterfalls (one that has yet to be run) and some steep boulder gardens make for varied if not "ultra-classic" whitewater.

name: Clendinning Creek
description: Quality 2 day boulder run with very continuous whitewater and stunning scenery.

name: Capilano River
description: A short run in North Vancouver flowing through a scenic canyon with easy whitewater.

name: Dipper Creek
description: Big waterfalls, mandatory class V, huge commitment.  Top tier adventure boating in a fantastic canyon.

name: Upper Pingston
description: One of B.C.'s best steep creeks. Classic whitewater; continuous, clean, few portages and a handful of bigger rapids. Not much is "must run", but be prepared to run a good amount of class 5 if you put on as either too much portaging or hiking out would be a lot of work and probably end in the dark. If the upper is too high the middle is a good back up option.

name: Eagle River
description: Remote wilderness expedition with easy whitewater Freshet usually starts in May and tapers off in July in the Cassiar region. The nearest gauge is in a different watershed, but may be helpful for estimating flows (COTTONWOOD RIVER ABOVE BASS CREEK (10AC005)). A flow of ~40cms may suggest a low but acceptable flow on the Eagle River Historical Max/Min/Mean Hydrometric Data Graph for COTTONWOOD RIVER ABOVE BASS CREEK (10AC005) [BC]. From a different drainage, but may represent flow conditions in the region.

name: Skagit River
description: A wilderness float through old growth forest

name: Mahatta River
description: A fun west coast canyon hidden at the end of the island. The Mahatta is a fairly low elevation watershed, and it is doubtful that there is any snowmelt season. A good west coast rain should get this going; for comparison, it is in a similar climatic zone as the Sarita River near Bamfield. There is no gauge on the Mahatta, but there is on the adjacent Klaskish River (KLASKISH RIVER NEAR KLASKINO INLET (08HE009)). A 20-30mm rain and the Klaskish gauge dropping off a 50cms spike resulted in a medium-high level on the Mahatta River. These rivers will flas

name: Chilliwack River
description: Some continuous boulder gardens especially at higher levels, pool drop, gravel bed, medium volume.

name: Tamihi Creek (Lower)
description: Manky boulder garden turning into steep committing canyon with fun class IV drops towards the end.

name: Benson River
description: A short low volume canyon in the middle of nowhere There are no gauges in this area, but the Upper Benson is a tight low volume creek, and low winter flows are probably best for a safe descent. At the put in, it should look like just enough flow to kayak. Any sort of big rain spike or high flows is going to be class V. This portion of the Benson River is above all the lakes, so flows may be flashy as is typical for the island. Furthermore, the Vanishing River is subtracted through a cave above the Upper Benson, and transferred to the Reappearing

name: Pitt River
description: Remote, multi-day wilderness run with tricky logistics and challenging paddling.

name: Ucona River
description: Technical waterfalls through coastal rainforest

name: White River (Nass tributary)
description: A high volume tributary to the Nass The White flows all summer, and likely correlates with the Nass gauge. It is not a small river, as it contributes a decent portion of the Nass directly from the massive Cambria Icefield. High water could get too boily. Information for this description is based on flows of 700cms in September (NASS RIVER ABOVE SHUMAL CREEK 08DB001).

name: Birkenhead River
description: Endless, top notch boulder drops that only get better as the run progresses.

name: Upper Callaghan
description: Scenic wilderness-feel but not far from a road. Lots to surf!

name: Downie Canyon
description: A short committing canyon with some fun technical rapids and beautiful scenery

name: Ashlu Mini Mine
description: A short intro to Ashlu paddling, bedrock rapids, boulder gardens and optional waterfall.

name: Puntledge River
description: A unique section consisting entirely of massive slides. Unpredictable dam releases. Flows in the Upper Puntledge are released from the BC Hydro's Comox Dam (PUNTLEDGE RIVER BELOW DIVERSION 08HB084).  Recommended flows for the Upper Puntledge are 80-120cms. BC Hydro provides release forecasts for the Comox Dam for the upcoming 3-4 days on its website. Use the "Forecast Puntledge River Gauge 6 Flow," not the "Forecast Comox Discharge." https://www.bchydro.com/energy-in-bc/operations/transmission-reservoir-data/reservoir-discharges/comox-dam.html The dam releases are most common j

name: Skookumchuck
description: Classic tidal rapid surfing.  Character changes with the speed of the current.  Awesome surroundings.

name: Homathko River
description: Big water wilderness multiday trip - world class.

name: Cowichan River
description: Consistently flowing class III canyon. Runnable flows in the fall, winter, and spring are fairly consistent by Island standards, fed by the large Cowichan Lake. As flows drop into the summer, a weir at the outlet of the lake retains enough water to release at very low levels. At the current summer base flow of ~7cms, the section is still technically runnable, but will very bony and overrun by inner tubers. A better low-medium flow is around 20-30cms. Unexpectedly, Marie Canyon is not a great high water run, and at flows around 100cms

name: Ashlu Creek
description: The last hurrah of the Ashlu.  Steep boulder piles that equate to difficult but good kayaking.

name: Chilliwack River – Post Creek to Camp Foley
description: Continuous boulder gardens, medium volum, rarely paddled, watch for wood.

name: Trent River
description: Park and huck waterfall and a mellow paddle out to the ocean The Trent needs heavy rains to come in. The minumum flow is 15 cms on BROWNS RIVER NEAR COURTENAY (08HB026). This gauge is in a different watershed so is only an approximation. The waterfall will be better higher, maybe around 50cms (see pictures below). For the lower run, the only high water limiting factor is the significant wood hazard.

name: Lillooet River
description: Stunning scenery multi-day option not far from Vancouver.

name: Rogers Creek
description: Short run in an amazing gorge - includes the famous triple falls.

name: Elaho River
description: A late season canyon run with fun whitewater at the end of the road in the Elaho Valley.

name: Bowser River
description: Paddle up close to several glaciers on this chain of lakes.

name: Stawamus River
description: A short novelty run in Squamish that's fun when everything in the area is running high.

name: Cheakamus – Paradise Valley
description: Fun beginner run : Low: 25 cms, Medium: 50 cms, High: 100 cms.

name: Clearwater River
description: The Ottawa of BC? Big volume, warm, playboating with big rapids.

name: Brittania Creek
description: A roadside double drop park and huck attraction with easy access and a sketchy take out.

name: Statlu Creek
description: Short but high quality, creamy smooth granite bedrock and boulders deep in the Fraser Valley.

name: Chehalis River
description: The best intermediate run in the Fraser Valley, down a wilderness canyon

name: Kicking Horse River
description: Classic, continuous river running. Fast, surging waves, powerful holes, satisfying eddies to play with.

name: Blanket Creek (Sutherland Falls)
description: A classic BC park and huck; one of the friendliest and most accessible large waterfalls out there

name: Troutline Creek
description: A novelty subalpine float, with stouts downstream left to explore Troutline Creek is probably best in early summer, as it is near the headwaters in an unglaciated area. June is probably best for the easy float through the upper valley. Sometime later in the summer, the lower canyons should drop into a reasonable flow, but they probably get too low at some point. The nearest gauge is in a different watershed, but may be helpful for estimating flows (COTTONWOOD RIVER ABOVE BASS CREEK (10AC005)). A flow of ~75cms on this gauge correlated to enough water for the u

name: Iskut River
description: An easy roadside float This section should be runnable all summer, it will be continuous during snowmelt in June. ISKUT RIVER AT OUTLET OF KINASKAN LAKE (08CG003). Gauge inactive.

name: Elk River
description: A short, stout run with challenging rapids and a clean 35 foot waterfall.

name: Yoho
description: Classic whitewater in an intimidating canyon.

name: White River
description: Classic lappable north Island canyon There is no online gauge on the White River, but the gauge on the Salmon River near Sayward can help to estimate flows. Appropriate flows happen in the days following rain events in the fall and winter, and more consistently during spring snowmelt. A minimum flow is 50cms on this gauge. At these flows, the White River Canyon is a pool drop class IV section with ample time to catch eddies and scout rapids. Anything over 100cms is getting high, and the river rapidly changes into a class V boily co

name: Adam River
description: Short quality intermediate granite canyon

name: McDame Creek
description: An easy roadside creek McDame Creek may be runnable all summer, although it will likely be high during freshet (June) and may be painfully low in the late summer. High water would be hazardous due to placer mining debris and cables in the river. July may be best. The nearest gauge is in a different watershed, but may be helpful for estimating flows (COTTONWOOD RIVER ABOVE BASS CREEK (10AC005)). A flow of ~40cms may suggest medium flows on McDame Creek Historical Max/Min/Mean Hydrometric Data Graph for COTTONWOOD RIVER

name: Gamsby River
description: Ultra-classic, coastal wilderness multiday.  3 days of white water.  2 days of flat.

name: Ryan River
description: Very steep boulder run - a hike-in day trip.  Hard kayaking.

name: Kokish River
description: One of the greatest class V runs on the Island.  A lengthy river full of complex boulder rapids in a lush canyon. Unfortunately it is dewatered for an IPP.

name: Cascade Creek
description: Steep, manky boulder rapids, a good bedrock canyon and some enormous waterfalls at the take out.

name: Bulkley Canyon
description: The Smithers classic run. Big water canyons with 'boogie water' and plenty of catch on the fly waves in between

name: Perry River
description: « Old Faithful » for the revelstoke paddler. One of the first runs to thaw and the last ones to dry up.

name: Beaver River (Kinbasket Canyon)
description: Early season warm up run with a linear class I to IV+ progression.

name: Upper Soo
description: Majestic tributary valley to the Whistler region.

name: Toby Creek
description: Beautiful class IV+ creeking that just keeps going and going! Easy access, minimal portaging, clean rapids and just enough spice to keep you focused. Since there is no online gauge or stick gauge it is a little tricky to know when this river is in. If it looks well within its banks, clear and even a little bony in the flatter/wider parts that you can see from the road it is most likely in. If it looks really bony it probably is. If it looks fast and full then it is almost certainly too high. The level is easier to tell from the put in than the takeout since it is so wide and meandering at the takeout.

name: Gordon River
description: A high water alternative to paddle when everything on the southern Island is flooding.

name: Similkameen River
description: Great novice run with warmer water than the coast

name: Ashnola River
description: Continuous river running in the hot and sunny Okanagan area of south central BC.

name: Moyeha River
description: A difficult traverse of a pristine watershed Look for the Gold (GOLD RIVER BELOW UCONA RIVER (08HC001)) to be around 100cms off snowmelt for a medium low kayaking level on the Moyeha, which can usually be found during spring snowmelt in May or June, depending on the snow year. 50cms on the Gold should be adequate for packrafting.

name: Granite Creek (Tulameen)
description: A decent low volume canyon run, but not recommended due to very dangerous mining adits The Tulameen watershed is on the dry side of the Coast Mountains, and the snowmelt season usually only lasts a few weeks in May and June. Granite Creek does not have a gauge, but at the takeout bridge the creek should look like you can get down without bumping rocks too much, but it shouldn't look high. The canyons upstream narrows to 3m width in places. There should be a decent correlation with the Tulameen gauges: a medium-low flow on Granite Creek equated to 20cms on Tulameen below Vuich Cree

name: Heber River
description: A box canyon ending at a baseball diamond

name: Clore River
description: A classic fly in multiday.  Steep, continuous rapids in a deep canyon with cheap and easy logistics.

name: Bobbie Burns Creek into Spillimacheen River
description: Lovely class 4 river running. Starts out as boulder gardens, slowly changing into bedrock rapids as the run progresses.

name: Koksilah River
description: A good introductory creeking run near Victoria

name: Lower Mamquam
description: Good beginner run with small rock garden

name: Tingle Creek
description: Beautiful clear turquoise waters, south of the Stave Valley.  The secluded Tingle Valley runs between Mount Robbie Reid, and the Justice Group (Judge Howay & The Defendant).

name: Chilko
description: Remote, beautiful clear water, big volume.

name: Stikine
description: A mellow way to experience the runout of the Grand Canyon Stikine Information for this description is based on flows of 250-500cms (Stikine River at Telegraph Creek). The section is likely runnable higher, although boils could become an issue, as well as other high water risks. Also, locals say the river doesn't freeze much in winter anymore, so off season low water descents may be possible as well.

name: Tatlow Creek
description: One of the best class V runs in SW BC.  Waterfalls, slides, electric blue water and difficult access.

name: Granite Creek
description: Waterfalls.  A great waterfall run with some boulder rapids and a lot of wood.

name: Cheakamus River
description: The hardest regularly run section of the Cheak - excellent boating in a good canyon with a few gnarly spots.

name: Seton River
description: A quick cool down in Lillooet.

name: Snowcap Creek
description: An obscure run near Rogers Creek with good whitewater and a short, hard to scout canyon in the middle.

name: Gilttoyees Creek
description: Coastal wilderness adventure with breathtaking scenery.  The whitewater is good but not classic.

name: Skookum Creek
description: Big, clean waterfalls and tight canyons. As of 2021, we have access to a gauge for Skookum Creek. This gauge is located just below the dam and represents the flow in the diversion reach -- what we kayak. We are still working to establish minimums and maximums but 8-15cms is a good starting point with 8 being quite low and 15 being higher than most would want it. Currently, the gauge updates once daily, but in the future we expect to gain access to more regular (hourly) updates.

name: Gun Creek
description: A 12 km long rapid.  Very continuous and splashy whitewater in a beautiful part of BC.

name: Callaghan Creek
description: Whistler's ultra classic.  Clean waterfalls, bedrock and boulder gardens.

name: Hirsch Creek
description: Great whitewater with a deep and committing canyon.  Beautiful scenery.

name: Lower Pingston
description: Hard charging BC creeking at its gnarliest. Hectic continuous class 5 with even scarier portages. Often full of wood. An absolute treat on its own or as the finisher to a long day of Pingston paddling. This page now shows flow information directly from Pingston dam at the top, but we are still working to understand the correlation between that gauge and runnability. The old correlation was based on the Cranberry Creek gauge : flows between 5 and 10cms are generally a good indicator.

name: Upper Tulameen
description: Remote, wilderness feel; low-volume canyons

name: Chilliwack Canyon
description: Pool-drop at low and medium, continuous at higher levels, bedrock and boulder gardens, medium volume river

name: Trout Creek
description: A microcreeking epic in wine country, tragically clogged with wood

name: Khtada River
description: A classic North Coast hike in mission. Large bedrock slides and rapids in the rainforest.

name: Green River
description: Surprisingly good whitewater on a Whistler run that sees little traffic.  Often tragically infested with wood.

name: Norrish Creek
description: Clean-ish boulders and bedrock with some very tight and deep canyons.

name: Stave River
description: Stout southwest BC multi-day kayaking.  There's unrealized opportunity to go big in there.

name: Prospect Creek
description: A creeky alternate entrance to Spius Creek; scenic but manky

name: Furry Creek
description: Short and stout park-n-huck waterfalls.

name: Wilson/Fitzstubbs Creek
description: A beautiful class fun paddling destination for all skill levels.

name: Small River
description: A Small River packed with big fun! Continuous class 3, be on the lookout for wood

name: Pingston
description: Excellent quality class 4 with a few bigger rapids near the end. Continuous without being pushy, clean read and run for the first 3/4 with reasonably easy scouting and portaging options for the bigger rapids

name: Foley Creek
description: An alternative start to the Chilliwack Canyon

name: Harris Creek
description: A short run in a small canyon on the southern end of Vancouver Island.  Nice class IV-V boating.

name: East Boulder Creek
description: A fantastic steep creek.

name: Spillimacheen
description: Short and sweet, Spilli has 5 major rapids with quality boogie water in between.

name: Bedwell River
description: A hike in multiday through the heart of Vancouver Island Look for the Gold (GOLD RIVER BELOW UCONA RIVER (08HC001)) to be around 100cms off snowmelt for a nice medium low level on the Bedwell, which can usually be found during spring snowmelt in May or June, depending on the snow year. Pacfish also maintains a staff gauge on the lower Bedwell River. Good levels may be between 0.6-1.0m, however this gauge is not regularly calibrated.

name: Cayoosh Creek
description: Nice river running through a deep, arid canyon.  Classic scenery and good whitewater.

name: Elaho-Squamish
description: Cold water and big waves : Low: Elaho 60 cms, Squamish 130 cms. Medium: Elaho 150 cms, Squamish 300 cms. High: Elaho 300 cms, Squamish 600 cms.

name: Douglas Creek
description: A short exciting run, with more to explore upstream.  A series of scenic waterfalls above from the small hydro dam infrastructure.

name: Cummins River
description: Remote, multi-day packraft trip through wild old growth rainforest

name: Nass River
description: Everything from a 5-6 day wilderness trip to a big water play run.

name: Blaeberry River
description: 2 short canyons. The first is a gorgeous class 2 slot canyon, the second is a short but intense class 5 canyon followed by a bit of class 3 run out.

name: Cariboo River
description: Big waves, some holes and boulders, a canyon, and flat water at the end. Large Volume

name: Coquitlam
description: 'Novelty' run. A few boulder gardens, gravel bars and flat water. Rarely paddled because its usually too low. Watch for wood.

name: Jordan River
description: The crown jewel of Revelstoke. « BC Class 4 » at it’s best.

name: Seymour River
description: Easy boulder gardens and gravel bars. Many boulder gardens, gravel bed, low volume; can be a challenge for beginners.

name: Squamish River
description: Amazing canyons - unless you're brave, it's an early or late season scenery trip.

name: Pamela Creek
description: One of the better creeks in Gold River - excellent bedrock ledges and waterfalls, with some classic Island mank.

name: St. Leon Creek
description: A steep, small creek with hectic boogie interspersed with some big, clean bedrock drops.

name: Kicking Horse
description: Scenic river running with significant wood hazard

name: Kleanza Creek
description: A fantastic North Coast creek run.  High caliber whitewater with a deep and beautiful bedrock canyon.  Wood is a common problem.

name: Big Mouth Creek
description: A beautiful wilderness adventure, cruising down continuous rapids, surrounded by many unique rock features and old growth forests.

name: Silverhope Creek
description: A good quality boulder run with tons of fun boogie.

name: Seymour River Canyon
description: Classic kayaking in a deep box canyon.  You would never know it's in the heart of North Van.

name: Grand Canyon of the Stikine
description: The most famous class 5 multiday in North America. Big volume paddling in a spectacular, committing canyon.

name: Stein River
description: A nice multiday trip on the arid side of the Coast Mountains.  Expect a lot of portages caused by wood.

name: Alsek River
description: One of the most spectacular northern wilderness trips in the world.  Challenging logistics, epic glaciers.

name: Hurley River
description: An impressive canyon with good class V whitewater.  A different feel from the typical Coast Mountain rivers.

name: Chilcotin River  (Chilko-Chilcotin-Fraser)
description: Classic multiday raft trip across the Chilcotin Plateau The Chilcotin has one of the most predictable river flows in BC since its sources are the enormous glacier-fed Chilko and Taseko Lakes.

name: Babine River
description: A classic, class 3/4 wilderness multiday.  Big water on the Skeena.

name: Goldstream Falls
description: Four sweet park and huck water

name: Big Silver Creek
description: Very committing granite gorge with big rapids, marginal waterfalls and hard portages.

name: Chemainus River
description: Good moderate difficulty whitewater with some beautiful canyons.

name: Tamihi Creek
description: Steep boulder gardens, continuous, low volume

name: Upana River
description: A short creek run in Gold River with a blind 20 footer

name: Thompson River – Goldpan to Frog
description: Lots of flat water with some powerful eddylines, whirlpools and a few waves, huge volume river.

name: Tutshi River
description: Fantastic big volume creeking.  The best and most accessible whitewater out of Whitehorse, Yukon.

name: Marble River
description: A scenic full day paddle with optional class V drops The Marble River has several large lakes which should regulate flow throughout the winter and spring, perhaps similar to the Cowichan River system. However, the class V drops on the Marble are going to be more runnable at low to medium levels in dry periods between rain events. During high water winter rains the class V rapids may get unreasonably high. The sweet spot to run all of the class V drops at a reasonable level might be in the late spring (May, June). The river is possibly runnable int

name: Muelville Creek falls
description: Two park and hucks in a beautiful canyon

name: McGregor Canyon
description: A really nice 5km (ish) canyon located northeast of Prince George. Great character to the whitewater.

name: Coquihalla River
description: Continuous boulder gardens, pool-drop, gravel bed, short bedrock canyon, some floating sections, medium volume.

name: Lens Creek
description: A local favorite on southern Vancouver Island.  An adventurous day of rapids, shuttling and portaging.

name: Boston Bar Creek
description: A park and huck next to the Coquihalla Highway

name: Tsable River
description: Steep, continuous and committing with various slides and drops.

name: Lynn Creek
description: A popular urban run with a picturesque canyon and fun rapids.  Optional waterfall at the start.

name: Thompson River
description: Big water boating in a warm climate with some play opportunities.  Interesting scenery.

name: Tulameen River
description: A chill run with an out of character class IV drop.

name: Coal River
description: A floaty wilderness multiday with an nice whitewater canyon at the end. There is no gauge on the Coal River, but you can get a general idea of flows from nearby gauges (Liard, Hyland, Nahanni). Flows generally rise high off snowpack melt into May and June, before gradually dropping through the rest of the summer. An early July trip (LIARD RIVER AT LOWER CROSSING @ 4000cms) was a fun medium high flow for kayaking. The guidebook Paddling in Yukon also describes this as a great August or September trip, including for decked canoes (LIARD RIVER AT LOWER CROSSING median

name: Slesse Creek
description: Low volume, gravel bed, many boulder gardens with a short narrow canyon section (“Keyhole Canyon”).

name: Cameron River
description: Excellent river-running with small canyons and bedrock rapids.

name: Kitsumkalum (Kalum) River
description: Big water play run.  At high water, one of the best play runs in BC.

name: Skookumchuck Creek
description: 16 km of high quality whitewater. River running at medium-high water with more of a creeky feel at medium-low water. : There is a painted rock gauge at the takeout. 1 is low, 3 is high. It can certainly be run higher, but does turn very fast and continuous with few eddies and shoreline trees become a real hazard. Typically this river runs at good flows in early to mid summer, after the spring flood.

name: Rutherford Creek
description: Continuous boulder rapids studded with some classic bedrock drops.

name: Nahatlatch River
description: A short but fun medium volume run on the dry side of the Coast Mountains.

name: Duti River
description: The Duti offers challenging whitewater in a spectacular remote wilderness setting.

name: Little Qualicum Falls
description: An exciting double drop draped in mystical Vancouver Island rainforest.

name: Meager Creek
description: A glacial read and run blitz underneath one of Canada's most unstable volcanoes.

name: Middle Memekay River
description: Nice long intermediate canyon run from a small creek down into a river.

name: Similkameen Canyon
description: Beautiful Deep Canyon running through some unique scenery

name: Nahatlach River – Francis Lake to Apocynum Campground
description: Medium volume, continuous boulder gardens, big holes, lots of fun.

name: Link River
description: The shortest river on Vancouver Island The Link River (upper Marble River on some maps) flows out of the large Victoria Lake, and is likely runnable consistently from October through May with the exception of very dry spells. Level is judged visually at the Southeast Main FSR bridge or at the campsite. If it looks like enough water to kayak, the canyon below the slides will be good to go. MARBLE RIVER AT OUTLET OF VICTORIA LAKE (08HE002). Limited historical gauge data from 1925-1931; 1932; 1933-1941; 1946-1953. Anything over 10cms sh

name: Seymour River – Upper Run
description: Pool-drop, some flat sections, gravel bed, low volume

name: Quesnel River
description: Big Volume, with play waves at the top. Home of the Unlikely Fest.

name: Fraser River – Alexandra Bridge to Yale
description: Huge volume, pool drop, big crashing waves and swirly eddies, lots of floating. The road is high above the river and accessible only in a few spots.
